title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: So long ago, so far away it was, that I had first evoked the faces and the mutual tragic situation of the men of Durisdeer.

title: Essays of travel and in the art of writing,
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: So long ago, so far away it was, that I had first evoked the faces and the mutual tragic situation of the men of Durisdeer.

title: Traditions of Edinburgh.
author: Chambers, Robert
snippet: His Grace's eldest son, James, was an idiot of the most unhappy sort — rabid and gluttonous, and early grew to an immense height ; which is testified by his coffin in the family vault at Durisdeer, still to be seen, of great length, and unornamented with the heraldric follies which bedizen the violated remains of his relatives.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: I had promised Mr R. Bogle and his sister to pass a few days with them at Moffat, on the road to which I passed one day with my friend William Cunningham,  minister of Durisdeer, the Duke of Queensberry' s parish church.

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " Whare will I get a bonny boyThat will win hose and shoon :That will gae down to Durisdeer,And bid my merry men come ?"

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: That will gae down to Durisdeer,And hid my merry-men come ?
